importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The population of North Atlantic right whales declined by about 25% from 2010 to 2020, marking a period of significant decline that highlights the urgency of conservation efforts.
The article was published on this date, reporting on the latest population estimate and signs of recovery in North Atlantic right whale numbers.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2010 to 2020 saw a 25% population decline in North Atlantic right whales, underscoring the severity of past threats and the need for stronger conservation measures.
The current period (2020–2025) shows a slow but positive trend in population growth, with the 2025 estimate indicating recovery after a decade of decline.

keyTakeAways: The North Atlantic right whale population has increased to an estimated 384 animals, up from 376 in the previous year, indicating a positive recovery trend.
This recovery is attributed to conservation efforts, including new management measures in Canada and protection under the Marine Mammal Protection Act.
The whales face ongoing threats such as ship collisions and entanglement in fishing gear, which remain significant challenges to long-term survival.
A key development is the birth of four calves by mother whales and shorter intervals between calves among established mothers, signaling improved reproductive health.
Despite a modest number of calves (11 in total), researchers are cautiously optimistic due to no observed mortalities and fewer injuries compared to previous years.
Environmental groups warn that continued threats to the Marine Mammal Protection Act and weakening of NOAA safeguards could jeopardize the recovery of this vulnerable species.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The North Atlantic right whale population has increased to an estimated 384 individuals in 2025, up from 376 in 2024, marking a slow but encouraging recovery after a 25% decline between 2010 and 2020. Scientists from the New England Aquarium’s Cabot Center and NOAA attribute this growth to conservation efforts, including new Canadian management measures in the Gulf of St. Lawrence and improved protection under the Marine Mammal Protection Act. Despite continued threats from ship collisions and fishing gear entanglements, recent signs of improved reproduction—such as four new calves and shorter intervals between births—offer cautious optimism. However, environmental groups like Oceana emphasize that the population remains on the brink of extinction and warn that legislative efforts to undermine marine protections could reverse progress. The article underscores the importance of sustained, science-based conservation to ensure long-term survival of this rare and vulnerable species.
title: North Atlantic Right Whale Population Shows Encouraging Recovery Amid Conservation Efforts
